dataset.title: Data From: TERRA REF, An Open Reference Data Set From High Resolution Genomics, Phenomics, and Imaging Sensors

abstract.para: The ARPA-E funded TERRA REF project generating open access reference datasets for the study of plant sensing, genomics, and phenomics. Sensor data are generated by a field scanner sensing platform that captures color, thermal, hyperspectral, and active flourescence imagery as well as three dimensional structure and associated environmental measurements. These data are provided alongside traditional field methods to support calibration and validation of algorithms used to extract plot level phenotypes from these datasets.

Data were collected at a field site in Maricopa, AZ that hosts a large field scanner with fifteen sensors, many of which are capable of capturing mm scale images and point clouds at daily to weekly intervals.

These data are intended to be reused, and are accessible as a combination of files and databases linked by spatial, temporal, and genomic information. In addition to providing open access data, the entire computational pipeline is open source, and we enable users to access high performance computing environments.

The study has evaluated a sorghum diversity panel, biparental cross populations, and elite lines and hybrids from structured breeding populations as well as a durum wheat diversity panel. This reference dataset can be used to characterize phenotype-to-genotype associations, on a genomic scale, that will enable knowledge-driven breeding and the development of higher-yielding cultivars of sorghum and wheat. The data is also being used to develop new algorithms for machine learning, image analysis, genomics, and optical sensor engineering.

para.quote: ,NA,NA,NA,NA In-season leaf area and biomass estimates by destructive sampling,

description.para: Plant biomass was sampled from 1 meter of row on 8 June 2016 and 29 June 2016. Stems were cut by hand near the soil surface and placed in a plastic bag for processing. The number of plants in the sample and canopy height were recorded in the field. The samples were then taken into the lab for processing. The number of main stems and tillers in the entire sample were counted. The entire sample was used on the 8 June 2016 sampling date and a subsample of 5 plants on the 29 June 2016 sampling date for further processing. This 5-plant subsample (June 29) was weighed as well as the entire sample. The leaves were then separated from the stems for leaf area measurements. The fresh weight of the leaves and stems were measured for the 29 June 2016 sampling date. Leaf area was measured using a LiCor area meter and leaf area index (LAI) calculated by dividing leaf area by land area of the sample measured. The land area representative of the leaf area measured was 0.762 m2 for the 8 June 2016 sampling date and 0.762 m2 times the subsample fraction for the 29 June 2016 sampling date. The subsample fraction is defined as the weight of the subsample divided by the weight of the total sample. The leaves and stems were then placed in an oven and dried at 65 C, and dry weight was measured after the plant material was dry. The biomass of the stems and leaves on a dry weight basis were calculated from the measured dry weight divided by the land area representative of the processed sample for each sampling date as discussed above for leaf area. Specific leaf area (for both sample dates) and dry matter fraction (for the June 29 sample date) were also calculated.

para.quote: ,Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center,2016, Leaf surface temperature and stomatal conductance estimates using hand-held instruments,

description.para: Repeat measurements were taken using hand-held instruments to estimate leaf surface temperatures and leaf stomatal conductance within 6-8 select plots (3-4 accessions x 2 replicates) on 7 dates in mid to late June 2017 (sorghum season 4) as part of a focused field phenotyping campaign related to stomatal regulation. Leaf surface temperatures were estimated using a FLIR TG167 Spot Thermal Camera (http://www.flir.com/instruments/tg167/) and an Apogee Infrared Radiometer Model MI-230 (https://www.apogeeinstruments.com/ultra-narrow-field-of-view-infrared-radiometer-with-handheld-meter-mi-230/). Measurements were taken on sunlit leaves, targeting fully expanded when possible, at a distance of approximately 20 to 40 cm above the leaf surface. Within each plot and at each measurement time, 6 total measurements were taken using the FLIR and Apogee instruments, with 3 measurements taken in each of the West and East subplot rows. Leaf stomatal conductance was measured using a Decagon SC-1 Porometer (https://www.decagon.com/en/canopy/canopy-measurements/sc-1-leaf-porometer-stomatal-conductance-measurements/). Within each plot and at each measurement time, 5 total measurements were taken using the porometer, on sunlit leaves targeting fully expanded leaves when possible. On each of the 7 dates when measurements were taken, early morning baseline equilibrium readings starting at 5:45 to 6:00 for one cycle through all 8 plots. Mid-day readings started at roughly 11:00 and continued through 3 repeat cycles of the 6-8 plots until roughly 15:00 to 16:00. The porometer was calibrated at least once in the early morning and again before the mid-day readings. The FLIR TG167 spot camera was tested against a thermal blackbody unit on 2017-06-21 (recorded 5 readings at 34.5 to 34.6 C while the thermal blackbody recorded 33.9 C). During the later measurement dates, 2 plots were dropped from the repeat measurement cycles because they had grown out of reach for hand measurements.

,Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center,2016, Leaf polyphenolics and chlorophyll measurements: Dualex Scientific+ leaf-clip handheld optical meter,

description.para: The optical leaf-clip meter (Dualex Scientific+) uses 5 LED light sources, including 1 UV-A, 1 read and 2 near-infrared (NIR) and a silicon photodiode detector to estimate chlorophyll content in leaves as well as flavonol and anthocyanin contents in the leaf epidermis. Measurements were taken on sunlit leaves in the upper canopy. Within each sampled plot, multiple subsample measurements were taken, each on different leaves, targeting fully developed sunlit leaves when possible. The instrument reports 5 measurements: 1) the temperature of the optical emitting head, 2) chlorophyll index (=(NIR trans. - Red trans.)/Red trans), 3) flavonol index (=Log(NIR fluo. excited red/NIR fluo. excited UV-A), 4) anthocyanin index (=Log(NIR fluo. excited red/NIR fluo. excited green), and 5) NBI (proprietary) nitrogen status, Chl/Flav ratio.

Measurements were conducted along a diagonal transect between the two plant rows of each sampled plot using the 45Â°view restrictor to hide the user from the sensor Field of View(FOV). para.quote: ,NA,NA,NA,NA Visual assessment of maturity stage at harvest,

description.para: Sorghum growth stage descriptions follow Vanderlip RL. 1993. How a sorghum plant develops. Manhattan, KS, USA: Kansas State University Cooperative Extension. Growth stages grouped by the following categories: vegetative growth prior to flag leaf emergence; flag leaf fully emerged; flowering (anthesis); early, mid, and late grain fill. Numerical categories: 1 = Vegetative; 2 = Flag leaf; 3 = Flowering; 4 = Early grain fill; 5 = Mid grain fill; 6 = Late grain fill. Early grain fill defined as time from flowering to milk or soft dough stages. Mid grain fill includes soft dough stage. Late grain fill defined as just past soft dough to physiological maturity.

para.quote: ,Field measurements from Maricopa Agricultural Center,2016, In-season per-plant leaf area and biomass estimates by destructive sampling,

description.para: Five plants of median height selected from all plants within 1 meter section of the plot row. The five destructively sampled plants were processed for per-plant leaf area and biomass estimates. All leaves, fully emerged and emerging, were removed from the main stem of each of the five plants and run through leaf area meter to estimate total leaf area per plant (cm2). Leaves of all five plants were pooled to measure combined leaf fresh weight. Main stems of all five plants were pooled to measure combined stem fresh weight. Leaf and stem samples were placed in drying oven at 60 C for two days. Dry weights of leaf and stem samples were measured as the combined weights of all five plants.
